When I burnt in desire to question them further, they made themselues Ayre, into which they vanish'd. Whiles I stood rapt in the wonder of it, came Missiues from the King, who all‑hail'd me Thane of Cawdor, by which Title before, these weyward Sisters saluted me, and referr'd me to the comming on of time, with haile King that shalt be. This haue I thought good to deliuer thee (my dearest Partner of Greatnesse) that thou might'st not loose the dues of reioycing by being ignorant of what Greatnesse is promis'd thee. Lay it to thy heart and farewell. %}

lines.text: Shall take vpon's what else remaines to do,

lines.speaker: Mal.
lines.text: According to our order.

lines.speaker: Sey.
lines.text: Fare you well:

lines.speaker: Sey.
lines.text: Do we but finde the Tyrants power to night,

lines.speaker: Sey.
lines.text: Let vs be beaten, if we cannot fight.

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: Make all our Trumpets speak, giue all breath

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: Those clamorous Harbingers of Blood, & Death.

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: They haue tied me to a stake, I cannot flye,

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: But Beare‑like I must fight the course. What's he

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: That was not borne of Woman? Such a one

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: Am I to feare, or none.

lines.speaker: Y. Sey.
lines.text: What is thy name?

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: Thou'lt be affraid to heare it.

lines.speaker: Y. Sey.
lines.text: No: though thou call'st thy selfe a hoter name

lines.speaker: Y. Sey.
lines.text: Then any is in hell.

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: My name's {% italic: Macbeth %}.

lines.speaker: Y. Sey.
lines.text: The diuell himselfe could not pronounce a Title

lines.speaker: Y. Sey.
lines.text: More hatefull to mine eare.

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: No: nor more fearefull.

lines.speaker: Y. Sey.
lines.text: Thou lyest abhorred Tyrant, with my Sword

lines.speaker: Y. Sey.
lines.text: Ile proue the lye thou speak'st.

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: Thou was't borne of woman;

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: But Swords I smile at, Weapons laugh to scorne,

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: Brandish'd by man that's of a Woman borne.

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: That way the noise is: Tyrant shew thy face,

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: If thou beest slaine, and with no stroake of mine,

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: My Wife and Childrens Ghosts will haunt me still:

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: I cannot strike at wretched Kernes, whose armes

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: Are hyr'd to beare their Staues; either thou {% italic: Macbeth %},

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: Or else my Sword with an vnbattered edge

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: I sheath againe vndeeded. There thou should'st be,

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: By this great clatter, one of greatest note

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: Seemes bruited. Let me finde him Fortune,

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: And more I begge not.

lines.speaker: Sey.
lines.text: This way my Lord, the Castles gently rendred:

lines.speaker: Sey.
lines.text: The Tyrants people, on both sides do fight,

lines.speaker: Sey.
lines.text: The Noble Thanes do brauely in the Warre,

lines.speaker: Sey.
lines.text: The day almost it selfe professes yours,

lines.speaker: Sey.
lines.text: And little is to do.

lines.speaker: Malc.
lines.text: We haue met with Foes

lines.speaker: Malc.
lines.text: That strike beside vs.

lines.speaker: Sey.
lines.text: Enter Sir, the Castle.

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: Why should I play the Roman Foole, and dye

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: On mine owne sword? whiles I see liues, the gashes

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: Do better vpon them.

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: Turne Hell‑hound, turne.

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: Of all men else I haue auoyded thee:

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: But get thee backe, my soule is too much charg'd

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: With blood of thine already.

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: I haue no words,

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: My voice is in my Sword, thou bloodier Villaine

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: Then tearmes can giue thee out.

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: Thou loosest labour,

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: As easie may'st thou the intrenchant Ayre

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: With thy keene Sword impresse, as make me bleed:

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: Let fall thy blade on vulnerable Crests,

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: I beare a charmed Life, which must not yeeld

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: To one of woman borne.

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: Dispaire thy Charme,

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: And let the Angell whom thou still hast seru'd

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: Tell thee, {% italic: Macduffe %} was from his Mothers womb

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: Vntimely ript.

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: Accursed be that tongue that tels mee so;

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: For it hath Cow'd my better part of man:

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: And be these Iugling Fiends no more beleeu'd,

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: That palter with vs in a double sence,

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: That keepe the word of promise to our eare,

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: And breake it to our hope. Ile not fight with thee.

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: Then yeeld thee Coward,

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: And liue to be the shew, and gaze o'th'time.

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: Wee'l haue thee, as our rarer Monsters are

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: Painted vpon a pole, and vnder‑writ,

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: Heere may you see the Tyrant.

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: I will not yeeld

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: To kisse the ground before young {% italic: Malcolmes %} feet,

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: And to be baited with the Rabbles curse.

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: Though Byrnane wood be come to Dunsinane,

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: And thou oppos'd, being of no woman borne,

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: Yet I will try the last. Before my body,

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: I throw my warlike Shield: Lay on {% italic: Macduffe %},

lines.speaker: Macb.
lines.text: And damn'd be him, that first cries hold, enough.

lines.speaker: Mal.
lines.text: I would the Friends we misse, were safe arriu'd.

lines.speaker: Sey.
lines.text: Some must go off: and yet by these I see,

lines.speaker: Sey.
lines.text: So great a day as this is cheapely bought.

lines.speaker: Mal.
lines.text: {% italic: Macduffe %} is missing, and your Noble Sonne.

lines.speaker: Rosse.
lines.text: Your son my Lord, ha's paid a souldiers debt,

lines.speaker: Rosse.
lines.text: He onely liu'd but till he was a man,

lines.speaker: Rosse.
lines.text: The which no sooner had his Prowesse confirm'd

lines.speaker: Rosse.
lines.text: In the vnshrinking station where he fought,

lines.speaker: Rosse.
lines.text: But like a man he dy'de.

lines.speaker: Sey.
lines.text: Then he is dead?

lines.speaker: Rosse.
lines.text: I, and brought off the field: your cause of sorrow

lines.speaker: Rosse.
lines.text: Must not be measur'd by his worth, for then

lines.speaker: Rosse.
lines.text: It hath no end.

lines.speaker: Sey.
lines.text: Had he his hurts before?

lines.speaker: Rosse.
lines.text: I, on the Front.

lines.speaker: Sey.
lines.text: Why then, Gods Soldier be he:

lines.speaker: Sey.
lines.text: Had I as many Sonnes, as I haue haires,

lines.speaker: Sey.
lines.text: I would not wish them to a fairer death:

lines.speaker: Sey.
lines.text: And so his Knell is knoll'd.

lines.speaker: Mal.
lines.text: Hee's worth more sorrow,

lines.speaker: Mal.
lines.text: And that Ile spend for him.

lines.speaker: Sey.
lines.text: He's worth no more,

lines.speaker: Sey.
lines.text: They say he parted well, and paid his score,

lines.speaker: Sey.
lines.text: And so God be with him. Here comes newer comfort.

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: Haile King, for so thou art.

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: Behold where stands

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: Th'Vsurpers cursed head: the time is free:

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: I see thee compast with thy Kingdomes Pearle,

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: That speake my salutation in their minds:

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: Whose voyces I desire alowd with mine.

lines.speaker: Macd.
lines.text: Haile King of Scotland.

lines.speaker: All.
lines.text: Haile King of Scotland.

lines.speaker: Mal.
lines.text: We shall not spend a large expence of time,

lines.speaker: Mal.
lines.text: Before we reckon with your seuerall loues,

lines.speaker: Mal.
lines.text: And make vs euen with you. My Thanes and Kinsmen

lines.speaker: Mal.
lines.text: Henceforth be Earles, the first that euer Scotland

lines.speaker: Mal.
lines.text: In such an Honor nam'd: What's more to do,

lines.speaker: Mal.
lines.text: Which would be planted newly with the time,

lines.speaker: Mal.
lines.text: As calling home our exil'd Friends abroad,

lines.speaker: Mal.
lines.text: That fled the Snares of watchfull Tyranny,

lines.speaker: Mal.
lines.text: Producing forth the cruell Ministers

lines.speaker: Mal.
lines.text: Of this dead Butcher, and his Fiend‑like Queene;

lines.speaker: Mal.
lines.text: Who (as 'tis thought) by selfe and violent hands,

lines.speaker: Mal.
lines.text: Tooke off her life. This, and what needfull else

lines.speaker: Mal.
lines.text: That call's vpon vs, by the Grace of Grace,

lines.speaker: Mal.
lines.text: We will performe in measure, time, and place:

lines.speaker: Mal.
lines.text: So thankes to all at once, and to each one,

lines.speaker: Mal.
lines.text: Whom we inuite, to see vs Crown'd at Scone.
